{{Infobox organization | name = Taos Institute | image = Taos_Institute.png | founded_date = 1991 | founder = [[Harlene Anderson]], [[David Cooperrider]], [[Kenneth Gergen]], [[Mary Gergen]], [[Sheila McNamee]], [[Suresh Srivasta]], and [[Diana Whitney]] | president = [[Kenneth Gergen]] | location = [[Chagrin Falls, Ohio]] | revenue = $549,867<ref name="Ratings">{{cite web | url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990_pdf_archive/760/760586294/760586294_201712_990.pdf | title=The Taos Institute | date=8 May 2018 | website=Foundation Center | accessdate=15 October 2018 }}</ref> | revenue_year = 2017 | expenses = $560,934<ref name="Ratings" /> | expenses_year = 2017 | homepage = {{URL|http://www.taosinstitute.net/}} }} '''The Taos Institute''' is an American non-profit association of scholars and practitioners dedicated to exploring [[social constructionist]] ideas.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The University of New Hampshire|title= Communication Conference to Explore Social Construction and Relational Practices|url=http://www.unh.edu/news/news_releases/1999/august/tm_19990810commconf.html|website=The University of New Hampshire|accessdate=22 November 2015}}</ref>
==Overview== The Taos Institute provides a newsletter, workshops, and consulting services.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Gene|title=The Taos Institute|url=http://www2.educause.edu/wiki/taos-institute|website=Educause|accessdate=26 November 2015}}</ref> Communities of mental health, social work, counseling, organizational change, education, community building, gerontology and medicine contribute to these offerings. The institute also serves as the home for the electronically distributed, ''Positive Aging Newsletter''<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Positive Aging Newsletter|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/positive-aging-newsletter|website=The Taos Institute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>and operates its own publishing company: Taos Institute Publications.<ref>{{cite web|title=Taos Institute Publications|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/s/%22Taos%20Institute%20Publications%22?Ntk=Publisher&Ns=P_Sales_Rank&Ntx=mode+matchall|website=Barnes & Noble|publisher=Barnes & Noble Booksellers, Inc.|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref>
There are presently approximately 500 associates representing over 20 nations.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Institute Associates|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/institute-associates|website=The Taos Institute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
==History== The Taos Institute was founded in 1991 by a group of scholars and practitioners interested in [[social constructionism|social constructionist]] ideas. The founders included [[Harlene Anderson]], [[David Cooperrider]], [[Kenneth Gergen]], [[Mary Gergen]], [[Sheila McNamee]], [[Suresh Srivastva]], and [[Diana Whitney]]. Primary attention was focused at that time on [[organizational development]] and [[family therapy]], with practices of [[appreciative inquiry]] and co-constructive practices of therapy prevailing. Most of the founders remain on the executive board, but have since been joined by Dawn Dole, Robert Cottor, Sally St. George, Jane Magruder Watkins, and Dan Wulff. The institute currently functions as a virtual centered organization.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Institute Officers and Board of Directors|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/institute-officers-and-board-of-directors|website=The Taos Institute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
The name of the Institute was derived, in part, from the fact that one of its founders, Diana Whitney, lived in [[Taos, New Mexico]], and provided a geographic center for possible meetings. In 1993, the Institute held its first international conference in Taos.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Brief History|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/brief-history|website=The Taos Insititute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
==Degree programs== The Taos Institute offers a Masters program and a PhD program in Relational Leading.<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Degree Programs|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/degree-programs|website=The Taos Institute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> It also offers a distance learning program (in conjunction with the [[Houston Galveston Institute]]).<ref>{{cite web|last1=The Taos Institute|title=Partnerships|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/partnerships|website=The Taos Institute|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.taosinstitute.net/}} *[http://taoslearning.ning.com Taos Online Community]

{{Infobox book | name = The Power of Half:
One Family's Decision to Stop Taking and Start Giving Back | title_orig = | translator = | image = Power of Half.jpg | caption = | author = Hannah Salwen,
Kevin Salwen | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = Consumption (economics) and consumer behavior; Moral and ethical aspects | genre = | publisher = [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] | pub_date = February 2010 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardcover;
Audiobook on CD | pages = 256 | isbn = 0-547-39454-3 | oclc = 317917971 | dewey = 174 22{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/power-of-half-one-familys-decision-to-stop-taking-and-start-giving-back/oclc/317917971?title=&detail=&page=frame&url=http%3A%2F%2Fcatdir.loc.gov%2Fcatdir%2Fenhancements%2Ffy1009%2F2009029971-d.html%26checksum%3D03199095eef1429928a694cb875c82ea&linktype=digitalObject |title=The power of half |publisher=WorldCat.org |date= |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} | congress = HC110.C6 S255 2010 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Power of Half: One Family's Decision to Stop Taking and Start Giving Back''''' is a book written by Kevin Salwen and his teenage daughter Hannah in 2010.{{cite news|last=Taylor|first=Ihsan|title=Paperback Row|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/16/books/review/PaperRow-t.html|accessdate=March 9, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 14, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Rosboch |first=Lili |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-21/family-sells-2-million-mansion-gives-half-to-charity-review.html |title=Family Sells $2M Mansion, Gives Half to Charity: Review |publisher=Bloomberg |date=June 21, 2010 |author= |accessdate=March 9, 2011}} The book describes how the Salwen family decided to sell their home so that they could donate half the proceeds to charity.{{cite news|url=http://www.oprah.com/world/Hannah-and-Kevin-Salwens-New-Book-The-Power-of-Half |title= A Surprising Path to Philanthropy |work=O, The Oprah Magazine |date=April 2010 |author=Rachel Mount |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} It discusses the initial decision-making, the process of selling the home, making the donation, downgrading to a smaller home, and what they learned in the process. The book details the Salwens' process in choosing a charity partner that would fit their values and effect a lasting change, and how their actions supporting and empowering a village in Ghana differed from their original idea of "direct involvement". ==Synopsis== The book details why and how the Salwen family decided to sell their home in 2006.{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/et-cetera/What-could-you-live-without/articleshow/5498358.cms |title=What Could You Live Without? |work=The Economic Times |date=January 25, 2010 |author= |accessdate=March 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127015718/http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News/News-By-Industry/ET-Cetera/What-could-you-live-without/articleshow/5498358.cms |archivedate=January 27, 2010 }} The home was a luxurious, 6,500-square-foot (600-square-meter), 1912 historic dream-house in [[Ansley Park]], in [[Midtown Atlanta|midtown]] [[Atlanta, Georgia]].{{cite news|url=http://moneywatch.bnet.com/saving-money/blog/ask-agent/atlanta-family-sells-house-donates-half-proceeds-to-charity/1496/ |title=Atlanta Family Sells House, Donates Half Proceeds to Charity |publisher=CBS MoneyWatch |date=February 15, 2010 |author=Allison Rogers |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} It had [[Corinthian column]]s, five bedrooms, eight fireplaces, four ornate bathrooms, and a private elevator to Hannah's bedroom.{{cite web|url=http://greenbuildingelements.com/2010/10/04/could-you-give-up-half-your-house/ |title=Could You Give Up Half Your House? |work=Green Building Elements |date=October 4, 2010 |author=Dawn Killough |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20100710/ZNYT01/7103010/-1/sports?p=all&tc=pgall |title=‘Daddy, Are We Rich?’ and Other Tough Questions |work=Herald Tribune |author=Ron Lieber |date=July 10, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Bland |first=Karina |url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/arizonaliving/articles/2010/03/21/20100321bland0321.html |title=Family lives on half the lifestyle, twice the joy |work=The Arizona Republic |date=March 21, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/families/article7060900.ece |title= Daddy, I want to help the poor–let’s sell the house; A daughter’s plea led one family to make a big gesture, but not everyone is applauding |work=The Sunday Times |date=March 14, 2010|author= John-Paul Flintoff |accessdate=March 9, 2011 |location=London}} The family down-graded by replacing their home with a house that was half as expensive and less than half the size.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/family-sells-15-million-home-half-price-village/story?id=9780698&page=1 |title=Family Sells $1.5 Million Home For One That's Half the Price to Help Village in Ghana |publisher=ABC News |date=February 8, 2010 |author= |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} The Salwens donated half the proceeds ($850,000) of the sale of their original home to [[The Hunger Project]], a charity that works to lessen the hunger of 30,000 rural villagers in over 30 villages in Ghana, and helps them gain self-reliance. The book describes the consensus-driven process that the parents and their two children used–over a period of time–to reach the decision to give away half the value of their home, and how they chose the charity from a number of [[non-profit organization]]s that they considered. It describes the challenges that the family faced while turning their family project into a reality, from economic ones to keeping the project a secret for a period of time so that they would not appear to be "freaks" to their friends.{{cite journal|author= [[Larissa MacFarquhar]] |url=http://www.newyorker.com/talk/2010/03/15/100315ta_talk_macfarquhar |title=A family makes a big donation to a village in Ghana |work=The New Yorker |date=January 7, 2009 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}} Before they embarked on the project, the family members had little contact with one another, other than at meals. Hannah notes that ''The Power of Half'' "is a relationships book, not really a giving book." She feels that the project helped her family grow closer to one another.{{cite news|last=Kellner |first=Jessica |url=http://www.naturalhomemagazine.com/green-professionals/the-power-of-half-natural-home-interviews-hannah-salwen.aspx |title=The Power of Half: Natural Home Interviews Hannah Salwen |work=Natural Home Magazine |date=September–October 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}} ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' notes how the family "became happier with less—and urges others to do likewise." "We know that selling a house is goofy, and we recognize that most people can't do it", admitted Kevin Salwen. "We never encourage anybody to sell their house. That was just the thing that we had more than enough of. For others it may be time, or lattes, or iTunes downloads, or clothes in their closet. But everyone has more than enough of something.” He clarified:
We want our kids to be idealistic, but we also say, ‘Let’s not go too nuts here'. We’re not Mother Teresa. We’re not taking a vow of poverty, or giving away half of everything we own. We gave away half of one thing, which happened to be our house. Everybody can give away half of one thing, and put it to use. You’ll do a little bit of good for the world–and amazing things for your relationships.
==Popular reception== [[Archbishop Desmond Tutu]] praised Hannah and the Salwens for the project, remarking: “We often say that young people must not let themselves be infected by the cynicism of their elders. Hannah inoculated her family with the vision to dream a different world, and the courage to help create it.” Skeptics criticized them for "self-promotion" or for the amount of money they donated to charity. Some critics questioned their choice of charity—finding fault with the family for having donated their money to help needy people in Africa rather than in the United States.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/lifestyle/family/articles/2010/07/31/are_they_courageous_or_reckless/?page=full |title=Are they courageous or reckless? |work=The Boston Globe |author=Joseph P. Kahn |date=July 31, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2010/05/02/1606381/nonfiction.html |title=Review | 'The Power of Half': A family decide to downsize, give back |work=Miami Herald |author=Lisa Bonos |date=April 30, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.grist.org/article/2010-02-10-i-paid-50-for-this-book-and-all-i-got-was-a-feeling-of-hope-and-/ |title=I paid $50 for this book and all I got was this lousy feeling of hope and goodwill |work=Grist |date=February 11, 2010 |author=Jen Halper |accessdate=March 9, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Tan |first=Caroline |url=http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2010/sep/24/author-speaks-about-giving-to-charity/ |title=Author speaks about giving to charity |work=Yale Daily News |date=September 24, 2010 |author= |accessdate=March 17, 2011}} Not everyone understood the parents' egalitarian approach with their children, or the family's underlying philosophy. Commented one viewer of a television interview: “What kind of ass clown works his tail off, and busts his hump getting a decent education, only to listen to his kid suggest they give away the house?” As Kevin Salwen noted: "Most people are supportive. And a few are very uncomfortable." Asked facetiously whether Hannah, then still in high school, had "concocted the world's greatest college-admissions ploy", Kevin laughed and replied: "No. Anyway, wouldn’t it be the world’s most expensive?"{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2010/02/13/one_familys_commitment_to_helping_others/ |title=One family’s commitment to helping others |work=The Boston Globe |date=February 13, 2010 |author=Joseph P. Kahn |accessdate=March 9, 2011}} ==Critical reception== Reviewing it for ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Lisa Bonos wrote that the book, "soaring in idealism, and yet grounded in realism, can show Americans of any means how best to give back."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/16/AR2010041602032.html |title=Book review: 'The Power of Half,' by Kevin Salwen and Hannah Salwen |work=The Washington Post|author=Lisa Bonos |date= April 18, 2010|accessdate=March 9, 2011}} [[Nicholas D. Kristof]], writing in ''[[The New York Times]]'', said he found the project "crazy, impetuous, and utterly inspiring", and that "It’s a book that, frankly, I’d be nervous about leaving around where my own teenage kids might find it. An impressionable child reads this, and the next thing you know your whole family is out on the street."{{cite news|last=Kristof|first=Nicholas D.|title=What Could You Live Without?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/24/opinion/24kristof.html|accessdate=March 9, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 23, 2010}} In the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Susan Salter Reynolds wrote: "You feel lighter reading this book, as if the heavy weight of house and car and appliances, the need to collect these things to feel safe as a family, are lifted and replaced by something that makes much more sense."{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/24/entertainment/la-ca-discoveries24-2010jan24 |title='The Power of Half' by Kevin and Hannah Salwen |publisher=Los Angeles Times |author=Susan Salter Reynolds |date=January 24, 2010 |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} Lili Rosboch wrote for [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] that it "is an inspiring book about the decision to trade objects for togetherness and the chance to help others." Writing in ''[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]'', Jen Harper said that while she was somewhat skeptical before she started the book, the "compelling and well-written narrative left me both impressed and inspired," and that she found the book "endearing, funny, and uplifting". Courtney E. Martin wrote in ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' that the book "is highly accessible, sure to be devoured by Oprah devotees and disaffected finance guys hoping for a jolt of optimism."{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-02-20/selling-the-housefor-charity/ |title=Selling Your House For Charity |work=The Daily Beast |date=February 20, 2010 |author= Courtney E. Martin|accessdate=March 10, 2011}} Bill Williams of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' called it "spirited".{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/books/articles/2010/02/15/the_power_of_half_is_full_of_inspiration/|title=‘The Power of Half’ is full of inspiration |publisher=The Boston Globe |author=Bill Williams |date=February 15, 2010 |accessdate=March 10, 2011}} Also writing for ''The Boston Globe'', Joseph P. Kahn said "they’re my new role models" – after admitting: "I confess to being fixated on the opposite life formula. Call it the Power of Twice. As in, twice the leisure time, twice the income, twice the sleep. A man can dream, can’t he?" ==Subsequent projects== The project inspired others to commit to donating half their money, or half of a possession or income, to charity. In an interview in ''[[Natural Home Magazine]]'', Hannah noted that “A number of my friends at Atlanta Girls School have started their own Half projects, including a couple who are donating half of their babysitting money to environmental causes. That’s pretty flattering." Rev. Tess Baumberger, the Minister at [[Unity Church]] of [[North Easton]], Massachusetts, read the book and announced that in December 2010 the Church would give away half of its Sunday collections to a local charity. Baumberger remarked: "What will we learn by practicing the power of half? What will this program teach our children and youth? I cannot wait to find out."{{cite news|author=Rev. Tess Baumberger |url=http://www.cantonrep.com/life/religion/x1617321451/Rev-Tess-Baumberger-Thanks-and-giving-the-power-of-half |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708114825/http://www.cantonrep.com/life/religion/x1617321451/Rev-Tess-Baumberger-Thanks-and-giving-the-power-of-half |archivedate=July 8, 2011|title= Thanks and giving–The Power of Half |work=CantonRep.com |date=November 23, 2010 |accessdate=January 14, 2016}} [[Melinda Gates]], wife of [[Microsoft]] founder [[Bill Gates]], said she was inspired by the Salwens' philanthropic efforts.{{cite episode |title=Bill Gates, Melinda Gates and Warren Buffett in an exclusive conversation about ‘The Giving Pledge’ |series=Charlie Rose |date=June 16, 2010 |url=http://www.charlierose.com/watch/50064709 |network=PBS |season=2010 |last=Rose |first=Charlie (host)}} On December 9, 2010, Bill Gates, [[Mark Zuckerberg]] ([[Facebook]]'s CEO), and investor [[Warren Buffett]] signed a promise they called the "Gates-Buffet [[Giving Pledge]]", in which they promised to donate to charity at least half of their wealth.{{cite news|last=Moss |first=Rosabeth |url=http://www.businessweek.com/managing/content/dec2010/ca20101214_945792.htm |title=Four Strategic Generosity Lessons|work=Business Week |date=December 14, 2010 |accessdate=March 9, 2011}} After launching the Giving Pledge, the Gates invited the Salwens to Seattle for a photo shoot and conversation about The Power of Half.{{cite news |url=http://www.motherearthnews.com/natural-home-living/a-rich-gift-homemade-jelly-for-bill-melinda-gates.aspx |title=A Rich Gift: Homemade Jelly for Bill and Melinda Gates |work=Mother Earth News |date=February 22, 2011 |author=Robyn Griggs Lawrence |accessdate=March 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110224045032/http://www.motherearthnews.com/natural-home-living/a-rich-gift-homemade-jelly-for-bill-melinda-gates.aspx |archivedate=February 24, 2011 |df= }} The '''three-term contingency''' (also known as the '''ABC contingency''') in [[operant conditioning]] describes the relationship between a behavior, its consequence, and the environmental context. The three-term contingency was first defined by [[B. F. Skinner]] in the early 1950s.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/191686|title=Science and human behavior|author=Skinner, B. F. (Burrhus Frederic)|date=1953|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=0029290406|location=New York,|oclc=191686}}</ref> It is often used within [[Applied behavior analysis|ABA]] to alter the frequency of socially significant human behavior.
== Components ==
=== Antecedent === The antecedent stimulus occurs first in the contingency and signals that reinforcement or punishment is available on the contingency of a specific behavior. A [[Discriminative stimulus|discriminative stimuli]], or S<sup>D</sup>, directly affects the likelihood of a specific response occurring.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/51566296|title=Behavior analysis and learning|last=David.|first=Pierce, W.|date=2004|publisher=L. Erlbaum Associates|others=Cheney, Carl D.|isbn=9780805844894|edition=3rd|location=Mahwah, N.J.|oclc=51566296}}</ref>
=== Behavior === The [[behavior]], also referred to as the response, is any observable and measurable action a living organism can do. In the three-term contingency, behavior is operant, meaning it changes the environment in some way.
=== Consequence === [[File:Operant conditioning diagram rev.svg|thumb|Diagram of consequences in operant conditioning]] The consequence to a behavior can be reinforcing or punishing. [[Reinforcement|Reinforcing]] consequences increase the likelihood of a behavior occurring in the future; it is further divided into positive and negative reinforcement. [[Punishment (psychology)|Punishing]] consequences decrease the likelihood of a behavior occurring in the future; like reinforcement, it is divided into positive and negative punishment.
The effectiveness and value of a consequence is determined by the [[Motivating operation|motivating operations]] the organism has. For example, deprivation of food can make food more effective as a consequence, and the satiation of hunger can make food less effective as a consequence.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/74942760|title=Applied behavior analysis|last=O.|first=Cooper, John|date=2007|publisher=Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall|others=Heron, Timothy E., Heward, William L., 1949-|isbn=0131421131|edition=2nd|location=Upper Saddle River, N.J.|oclc=74942760}}</ref>

'''Tschandala''' (old German transcription of ''[[chandala]]'') is a term [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] borrowed from the [[Indian caste system]], where a Tschandala is a member of the lowest social class. Nietzsche's interpretation and use of the term relied on a flawed source but was used by some interpreters to connect him to [[Nazi ideology]]. == Nietzsche's use of the term == Nietzsche uses the term "Tschandala" in the ''Götzen-Dämmerung'' (''Twilight of the Idols'')"Die ‚Verbesserer‘ der Menschheit" (KSA 6, p. 98–102) and ''Der Antichrist'' (''The Antichrist'').chapter 56 and 57 (KSA 6, p. 239–244) Here he uses the "[[law of Manu]]“ with its [[Caste system in India|caste system]] as an example of one kind of morality, of "breeding", as opposed to the Christian version of morality which attempts to "tame" man. At first, Nietzsche describes methods of [[Christianity|Christian]] attempts to "improve" humanity. As a metaphor, he uses a trained beast in a menagerie which is said to be "improved", but which in reality has lost vitality and is only weakened. In just such a way, Nietzsche says, has Christianity "tamed" the Teutonic races. The law of Manu, on the other hand, tries to "improve" humanity by creating 4 castes of people, while ostracizing and making life miserable for the Tschandala, the untouchables. Nietzsche deplores this type of morality, that of the "breeder," just as he does the (Christian) "animal tamer", as he is opposed to all 'morality'. However, he much prefers it to the Christian "slave-morality." In his view, the humiliating and oppressive edicts against the Tschandala are a defensive means of keeping the castes pure:
Yet this organization too found it necessary to be ''terrible''—this time not in the struggle with beasts, but with their counter-concept, the unbred man, the mishmash man, the chandala. And again it had no other means for keeping him from being dangerous, for making him weak, than to make him ''sick''—it was the fight with the "great number.[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/7203 Götzen-Dämmerung], Die "Verbesserer" der Menschheit
According to Nietzsche, Christianity is a product of [[Judaism]], the "Tschandala-religion". By this he means that Judaism and Christianity after it are the morality born of the hatred of the oppressed (like the Tschandala) for their oppressors:
Christianity, sprung from Jewish roots and comprehensible only as a growth on this soil, represents the ''counter-movement'' to any morality of breeding, of race, privilege:—it is the ''anti-Aryan'' religion par excellence. Christianity, the revaluation of all Aryan values, the victory of chandala values, the gospel preached to the poor and base, the general revolt of all the downtrodden, the wretched, the failures, the less favored, against "race": the undying chandala hatred as the ''religion of love''...
In ''[[The Antichrist (book)|The Antichrist]]'', Nietzsche again cites the law of Manu, and favors it in a relative sense to the morality of Judeo-Christianity. Nietzsche describes the "most spiritual" and "strongest" men who can say "yes" to everything, even the existence of the Tschandalas; and opposed to this is the envious and revengeful spirit of the Tschandalas themselves (cf. [[master-slave morality]]). Nietzsche also uses the term Tschandala for some of his opponents, e.g. [[socialism]]. == Nietzsche's flawed source == Nietzsche's source for the law of Manu was the book ''Les législateurs religieux. Manou, Moïse, Mahomet'' (1876) by French writer [[Louis Jacolliot]]. According to Annemarie Etter, this translation of the [[Manusmriti]] is not reliable and differs widely from other sources.Annemarie Etter: ''Nietzsche und das Gesetzbuch des Manu'' in: ''Nietzsche-Studien'' 16 (1987), p. 340–352 For example, the high respect it gives to women, which Nietzsche quotes in opposition to "Christian misogyny", is in fact not contained in any of the usual texts. In his description and interpretation of the "Tschandala", Nietzsche may have followed a long footnote by Jacolliot, which gives an "unbelievable, abstruse and scientifically completely untenable" (Etter) theory. According to Jacolliot, all [[Semitic peoples]], especially the Hebrews, are descendants of emigrated Tschandalas. Although Nietzsche never directly says this, it seems plausible that he believed in Jacolliot's theory at least to some extent, even though, as Etter points out, Nietzsche would have easily been able to falsify several of Jacolliot's [[pseudo-science|pseudo-scientific]] claims. In so doing, he may have increased the impact of Jacolliot's "effusive admiration for ancient Eastern wisdom and civilization with a more or less open and pronounced antisemitism and antichristianism" (Etter). ==Descendant uses== === Nazi Germany=== Terms like "race", "breeding", "[[Aryan]]" and others Nietzsche used in his later works were employed by Nazi polemicists who referenced his theories. Though Nietzsche did use the term ''[[Übermensch]]'', ''nowhere'' in his works he used the contrary ''[[Untermensch]]'' that in the 20th Century became a concept in Nazi ideology, that was used for races and individuals that it perceived ''"inferior"''. === Literary influence === Inspired by Nietzsche, [[August Strindberg]] wrote a novel called "Tschandala" in 1889. ==Further reading== *Koenraad Elst: Manu as a Weapon against Egalitarianism. Nietzsche and Hindu Political Philosophy, in: Siemens, Herman W. / Roodt, Vasti (Hg.): Nietzsche, Power and Politics. Rethinking Nietzsche’s Legacy for Political Thought, Berlin / New York 2008, 543-582. == References == {{reflist}} {{Nietzsche}} [[Category:Friedrich Nietzsche]] [[Category:Social concepts]]

'''Women human rights defenders''' (WHRDs) are women who defend [[human rights]], and defenders of all genders who defend the rights of women and rights related to gender and sexuality.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org/about/|title=About WHRDIC {{!}}|website=www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.awid.org/priority-areas/women-human-rights-defenders|title=Women Human Rights Defenders|date=2014-12-17|work=AWID|access-date=2018-05-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/HRC/16/44|title=Report of the Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights defenders, Margaret Sekaggya (2010)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.un.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> Their work and the challenges they face have been recognized by a [[United Nations resolution|United Nations (UN) resolution]] in 2013, which calls for specific protection for women human rights defenders.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ishr.ch/news/un-adopts-landmark-resolution-protecting-women-human-rights-defenders|title=UN adopts landmark resolution on Protecting Women Human Rights Defenders|work=ISHR|access-date=2018-05-13|language=en}}</ref> [[File:Women_Human_Rights_Defenders_International_Coalition_Logo.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Women_Human_Rights_Defenders_International_Coalition_Logo.jpg|thumb|This is the logo for the Women Human Rights Defenders International Coalition that represents the coming together and discussing problematic issues dealing with human rights for all.]] The United Nations' resolution deals with human rights and resolutions to issues that are presented at hand. It should be noted that the resolutions developed are intended to be implemented into the communities of the world but not legally enforceable under law.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_resolution|title=United Nations Resolution|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
A woman human rights defender can be an Indigenous woman fighting for the rights of her community, a woman advocating against torture, an [[Intersex and LGBT|LGBTQI]] rights campaigner, a sex workers’ rights collective, or a man fighting for sexual and reproductive rights.<ref name=":0" />
Like other [[human rights defenders]], women human rights defenders can be the target of attacks as they demand the realization of human rights. They face attacks such as discrimination, assault, threats, and violence within their communities. However, women human rights defenders face additional obstacles based on who they are and the specific rights they defend. This means they are targeted just because they are women, LGBTI people or for identifying with their struggles. They also face additional obstacles connected with systemic discrimination and inequality and because they challenge, or are seen to be challenging, patriarchal power and social norms. They are more at risk of facing gender based violence in the home and the community, and sexist, misogynistic, homophobic, trans-phobic threats, smears and stigmatization, as well as exclusion from resources and power.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/act30/6011/2017/en/|title=Document|website=www.amnesty.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20936&LangID=E|title=OHCHR {{!}} International Women Human Rights Defenders Day –29 November 2016|website=www.ohchr.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref> The women that work to fight for human rights have numerous meetings with the UN Human Rights Council in conjunction with the LGBTQI defenders in Uganda who face prejudice and discrimination as well for The Women Human Rights Defenders understand the struggles being endured.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org/our-work/|title=Our Work {{!}}|website=www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>
International Women Human Rights Defenders Day has been celebrated each 29 November since 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20936&LangID=E|title=OHCHR {{!}} International Women Human Rights Defenders Day –29 November 2016|website=www.ohchr.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-13}}</ref>
== Examples of contemporary WHRDs == {{Unreferenced|date=May 2018}} * [[Morena Herrera]] (El Salvador) * [[Estela de Carlotto]] (Argentina) * {{ill|Aura Lolita Chavez|de|Aura_Lolita_Chavez_Ixcaquic}} (Guatemala) * [[Maxima Acuna]] (Peru) * [[Sonia Pierre]] (Haiti) * {{ill|Su Changlan|zh|苏昌兰}} (China) * [[Leila de Lima]] (Philippines) * [[Angkhana Neelaphaijit|Angkhana Neelapaijit]] (Thailand) * [[Hina Jilani]] (Pakistan) * [[Azza Soliman]] (Egypt) * [[Narges Mohammadi]] (Iran) * [[Loujain Alhathloul|Loujain Al-Hathlou]] (Saudi Arabia) * [[Katana Gégé Bukuru]] (DR Congo) * [[Salimata Lam]] (Mauritania) * [[Delphine Djiraibe]] (Chad) * [[Lydia Foy]] (Ireland) * [[Marjan Sax]] (Netherlands) * {{ill|Anina Ciuciu|fr|Anina_Ciuciu}} (France/Romania) * [[Anna Mokrousova]] (Ukraine)
These are some of the WHRDs killed in recent years, because of their human rights activism
* [[Berta Cáceres]] (Honduras) * [[Marielle Franco]] (Brazil) * [[Miroslava Breach]] (Mexico) * [[George Tiller|Dr George Tiller]] (USA) * [[Gauri Lankesh]] (India) * [[Xulhaz Mannan]] (Bangladesh) * [[Noxolo Nogwaza]] (South Africa) * [[David Kato]] (Uganda) * [[Natalya Estemirova|Natalia Estemirova]] (Russia) * [[Hande Kader]] (Turkey) * [[Salwa Bughaighis|Salwa Bugaighis]] (Lybia)
See also [[List of women killed fighting for human rights]].

__NOTOC__ {{infobox book | | name = Workers
工人 | title_orig = | translator = | image = Workers cover. gong ren.jpg | caption = Cover image | author = [[Helen Couchman]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = [[English language|English]]; [[Chinese language|Chinese]] | series = | genre = [[Artist's Book]] | publisher = [[Soloshow Publishing]] | release_date = June 2008 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]]) | pages = 152 pp (first edition, hardback) | isbn = 978-0-9560172-0-8 | isbn_note = (first edition, hardback) | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''Workers''' ({{zh|t=工人|s=工人|p=gongren}}) is a book of 143 portraits of migrant workers who participated in the construction of the [[Olympic Green]] in [[Beijing]], [[China]] in the lead up to the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. The book is the work of British artist Helen Couchman and consists primarily of photographs of the workers on the building site. The workers were photographed with the iconic buildings of the Beijing Olympics: The [[Beijing National Stadium]] (国家体育场), known colloquially as the "Bird's Nest" (鸟巢), and the [[Beijing National Aquatics Center]] (国家游泳中心), also known as the "Water Cube" (水立方). [[File:Jhang Gao pages 22-23.jpg|thumb|left|300px|
Portrait of Zhang Gao and his signature from the series ''Workers 工人''
]] == Background == At the height of its construction, nearly 17,000 workers were involved in building the "Bird's Nest".{{cite news |first= Nick|last= Mulvenney|author2=Alex Richardson |title= Beijing says 2 died in Bird's Nest construction|url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUKPEK10105320080128?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true|publisher= [[Reuters]]|date= 28 Jan 2008|accessdate=29 May 2011}} ''Workers 工人'' documents the human side of construction with worker portraits, information on the workers themselves, and details on how Couchman carried out the project. In December 2007, Couchman circumvented security on the Olympic construction site and was able to approach the workers about taking their pictures.Toy, Mary-Anne. [http://www.theage.com.au/world/silent-workers-get-their-moment-to-shine-before-the-games-begin-20080807-3rjd.html "Silent workers get their moment to shine before the games begin"], ''The Age'', 7 August 2008. Retrieved 29 May 2011.Mishan, Ligaya. [http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2008/06/work-unit.html "The Book Bench, WORK UNIT"], ''The New Yorker'', 19 June 2008. Retrieved 29 May 2011. She later returned to the site with two copies of each photo, giving each of her subjects one copy to keep and asked the workers to write their name and hometown on the other.Levin, Dan. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/arts/design/10expatsweb.html?_r=1 "For Expatriates in China, Creative Lives of Plenty"], ''The New York Times'', 8 January 2010. Retrieved 29 May 2011 Couchman felt that the element of exchange was key to this project.Ghomeshi, Jian. [http://podcast.cbc.ca/mp3/qpodcast_20080630_6503.mp3 "Q: Arts and Culture"], ''CBC Radio'', 30 June 2008, Retrieved 13 July 2010. == Reception == In the book's introduction, British art critic Peter Suchin writes that the way Couchman positions the workers at roughly the same spot for each portrait suggests they can also be seen as "one single portrait, that of `the worker' engaged in the making of the Place of the Games ... the central focus, the essential signifier of the new Beijing". Photographs from this series were exhibited in [[London]], England and [[Hong Kong]]. Discussions of workers' rights have been raised in the context of this book, but it was not Couchman's reason for starting the project.Ng, Tse-wei. [http://olympics.scmp.com/Article.aspx?id=1773§ion=insight "The faces behind the Beijing landmarks"], ''South China Morning Post'', Hong Kong, 31 July 2008. Retrieved 29 May 2011. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.helencouchman.com/portfolio-items/workers-gongren Workers 工人 (official website)] * [http://www.helencouchman.com Helen Couchman] [[Category:Artists' books]] [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:British art]] [[Category:Construction trades workers]] [[Category:2008 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic Games books]] [[Category:2008 books]]
